Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Stress Appraisal and Working Memory Function
Award.AbstractNarration:
Working memory, a critical cognitive function, is a strong predictor of academic, professional, and overall life achievement. Individuals differ greatly in their working memory abilities and such variation could be due to conditions that tax the working memory system, such as stress. Research examining the influence of stress on cognition through the presentation of negative feedback, however, has yielded conflicting results. With the help of Dr. Qiong Zhang at Zhejiang University, the current proposal examines how individual differences such as appraisal of negative feedback mediate the relationship between stress and working memory function.

The project examines how one?s appraisal of feedback influences their performance. Individual differences in response to feedback could be rooted in the stress perception. Fundamental to the perspective of psychological stress is the perception and evaluation of potential harm posed by the stressor. Thus, psychological stress is solely determined by the persons? interpretations of the situation and not by objective appraisal of the environmental experiences. In the proposed study, subjects will be assigned to one of two conditions where they will be given positive or negative fictitious feedback on the working memory task irrespective of their actual performance. The influences of this feedback on working memory performance will be examined by assessing individual variables that may predict whether a stressor is perceived as a threat or a challenge. Amongst others, one such variable could be cultural background as previous research has indicated differences between East Asian and Western cultures in response to feedback. This NSF EAPSI award supports the research of a U.S. graduate student and is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The use of feedback aimed to improve performance is ubiquitous, particularly in education. Feedback is used to improve learning though little is actually known about the underlying mechanisms of such feedback. In fact, the empirical work attesting to its efficacy is rife with contradictions. Building off my interest in affect and cognition, my project examines the variability of working memory (WM) following fictitious feedback. Additionally, measures of stress, anxiety, grit between participants in the U.S. and China are used to identify individual characteristics that may account for differential outcomes. Our findings reveal differences in the performance of participants from U.S. and China. We found that individual characteristics, specifically grit and country, influenced WM performance following feedback. The differential effects of grit on WM performance following feedback between participants in the US and in China highlight the moderating effects of individual difference variables on Feedback.

The data from the present study may suggest two note-worthy trends: 1) the WM performance of participants in the U.S. is susceptible to the influences of feedback; and 2) positive feedback improves WM performance for U.S. participants with low grit. The general expectation is that negative affect impairs performance while positive affect improves performance, but the present results indicate that this is only the case for participants in the U.S., particularly those with lower levels of grit. A universal model of affect and cognition currently does not exist primarily because the underlying mechanisms are mediated by individual variables, such as motivation. Together, the development of such a model would corroborate the Cognitive Interference Theory (Sarason, 1984; Sarason, Sarason, & Pierce, 1990, 1995) explaining that the link between evaluation anxiety and diminished cognitive performance lies in the vulnerability from an individual’s tendency to devalue their capacity and exaggerate the degree of threat in the situation leading to a loss of motivation. Thus, future studies are needed to consider the indicators, such as motivation, that lead to perceptions that drive effort mobilization.

            A clearer presentation of WM variability, particularly in the face of negative affect, may help us understand which individual factors help maintain cognitive function in spite of stress. Such work is critical in facilitating the development of programs aimed to optimize performance outcomes. The well-documented effect of anxiety on education outcomes (Owen, Stevenson, Norgate, & Hadwin, 2008) appears to be mediated by WM performance (Aronen, Vuontela, Steenari, Slami, & Carlson, 2005; Beilock & Carr, 2005). Thus, minimizing the negative impacts on cognitive function in the face of anxiety has clear implications in education and a child’s general well-being. The present study aimed to identify factors that would help us understand when feedback enhances or diminishes cognitive performance by examining the individual difference variables. Moreover, future studies examining the influence of motivation ought to be carefully considered, with follow up study including measures examining state and change of motivation during the task. Understanding how to optimize cognitive performance particularly in the face of stress could inform educational practices and help students learn more effectively.
